docs.snippet: The Synod resumed its session yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. After some time passed in devotional exercises, reports from the various Committees were taken up and considered. The first report was on the subject of the Sabbath, means for its better...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Synod resumed its session yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. After some time passed in devotional exercises, reports from the various Committees were taken up and considered. The first report was on the subject of the Sabbath, means for its better ob servance being therein suggested.

docs.snippet: Hon. GEORGE MOREY, Treasurer of the Boston Committee to aid the Union Volunteers of St. Louis, sent $1,000 yesterday as the first installment of the subscription, and telegraphed the fact to Col. BLATE.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hon. GEORGE MOREY, Treasurer of the Boston Committee to aid the Union Volunteers of St. Louis, sent $1,000 yesterday as the first installment of the subscription, and telegraphed the fact to Col. BLATE.

docs.snippet: The British and North American Royal Mail steamship Karnak, Capt. LE MESSUREIER, arrived at her wharf last evening at 6 P.M., from Havana May 11, and Nassau, N.P., 13th inst., with a large freight of segars, , and 128 passengers from the above ports.

headline.main: From Havana and Nassau.; ARRIVAL OF THE KARNAK.

docs.lead_paragraph: The British and North American Royal Mail steamship Karnak, Capt. LE MESSUREIER, arrived at her wharf last evening at 6 P.M., from Havana May 11, and Nassau, N.P., 13th inst., with a large freight of segars, , and 128 passengers from the above ports.

docs.snippet: MY DEAR : I have promised myself for some time that I would write you fully. I always endeavor never to break a promise, and had I not also promised you I think I should have broken the promise to myself.

headline.main: FROM THE NEW-YORK TWELFTH.; FROM THE NEW-YORK TWELFTH. LETTER FROM CAMP ANDERSON HARDSHIPS OF THE REGIMENT AND HOW THE MEN MET THEM. HEADQUARTERS TWELFTH REGIMENT, CAMP ANDERSON, WASHINGTON, Monday, May 13, 1861.

docs.lead_paragraph: MY DEAR : I have promised myself for some time that I would write you fully. I always endeavor never to break a promise, and had I not also promised you I think I should have broken the promise to myself.

docs.snippet: I learn from very good authority that Col. JONES, Who led the glorious Massachusetts Sixth through Baltimore on the 19th ult., will succeed Gen. BUTLER in the Brigadier-Generalship.

headline.main: LATEST NEWS OF THE REBELLION.; SPECIAL DISPATCH FROM WASHINGTON.

docs.lead_paragraph: I learn from very good authority that Col. JONES, Who led the glorious Massachusetts Sixth through Baltimore on the 19th ult., will succeed Gen. BUTLER in the Brigadier-Generalship.

headline.main: THE ARMY AND NAVY.; STRENGTH OF THE BLOCKADING FLEET. IMPORTANT MILITARY AND NAVAL NEWS.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is not, as yet, any definite organization of the blockade fleet, Annexed, however, are the names of the vessels, with armuments on board, which have been commissioned to guard the different ports. None of the regular vessels ordered are inserted, except those on active duty or almost ready for their crews:

headline.main: Death of Mr. Keese Official Correspondence,
A Word in Season on an Important Subject.
